text: I have considerable background in front-end web development having worked multiple jobs in the field using technologies such as Javascript/ES6, Typescript, CSS, Less, Sass, jQuery, AngularJS, React and Electron. I also have experience building browser extensions for Google Chrome.

At past companies I've had extensive experience writing server-side code in both node.js and Ruby, using frameworks such as express.js, Rails and Sinatra. I've written servers for personal projects, as well as configuring the DNS for them.

I am highly experienced with object-oriented programming, having taken multiple courses in C and C++. These courses have involved group projects in which I have taken the role of team lead and have also designed the structure of the entire multi-thousand line program.

Past jobs have had me using MySQL often, writing many complex queries and optimizing table indices. I've also written synchronous migrations on large tables (~2 billion ids) using a company-internal fork of LHM.

I have used Amazon Web Services in past co-op jobs, particularly EC2, ECS and IAM, though I'm also familiar with S3, SQS, Elastic Beanstalk, Kinesis, OpsWorks and CloudWatch. I've been tasked with creating new staging instances, as well as first-time setup of new microservices. I've also hosted personal projects on Heroku.

At past companies I have developed on all of Windows, OS X and Unix/Linux environments and would consider myself comfortable coding on each of them. Bash scripting has become a regularly used tool in this way.

I have worked extensively with several version control softwares such as Git, Github and Mercurial in the contexts of university classes, independent projects and work environments. I have also researched into these technologies for past work term reports.

At all my previous companies I have worked on research projects, quickly producing detailed proof-of-concepts for technologies such as Electron, Aurelia, Parsehub, DialogFlow and the Google Web Speech API. At Flipp I researched a long-standing issue surrounding stale database locks and designed a solution to fix it.

In my 2B term I took Physics 239: Computational Physics. Using both C++ and Octave, a free version of Matlab, this course teaches an object‚Äêoriented approach to many physics problems, with more general methods taught as well, such as solving differential equations and Monte Carlo techniques.
